title: Johan de Aguas
text:
I am a PhD student at the Faculty of Mathematics and Natural Sciences (MatNat) at the University of Oslo (UiO), under the supervision of Dr. Johan Pensar. Concurrently, I am a researcher at the Norwegian Institute of Public Health (NIPH), under the supervision of Dr. Guido Biele.
I hold baccalaureate degrees in industrial engineering and in economics, from Universidad de los Andes (UniAndes) in Colombia; plus master’s degrees in economics and in statistics, the latter from Michigan State University (MSU). I am an international Fulbright scholar (2019).

title: Johan de Aguas
text:
Research
My research interests, accumulated knowledge and experience gravitate around:

Causal inference with observational data
Epistemic uncertainty quantification for machine learning and causal inference
Statistics + game theory: strategic complements networks, and dynamic treatment regimes

title: Blog
section: When selection depends on mediation: part 1
text:
When selection depends on mediation: part 1
We review the motivation and assumptions for the inverse probability weighting (IPW) estimator of the average treatment effect (ATE) using experimental data (randomized treatment assignment) affected by selection bias. The IPW estimator of the ATE can be expressed in terms of:
\[
\hat{\mathbb{E}}[Y\mid do(A=a)]= N^{-1}\sum_{i=1}^N \mathbb{I}[A_i=a] v_i(a)\cdot w_i\cdot y_i
\]
We check consistency and present a small simulation for the case where the selection mechanism depends on the treatment assignment and other pre-treatment variables.
We open the discussion for the case where the selection mechanism depends on a mediator of the effect as well.

title: Blog
text:
Recovering from selection bias
We review the motivation and assumptions for the inverse probability weighting (IPW) estimator of the average treatment effect (ATE) using experimental data (randomized treatment assignment) affected by selection bias. The IPW estimator of the ATE can be expressed in terms of:
\[
\hat{\mathbb{E}}[Y\mid do(A=a)]= N^{-1}\sum_{i=1}^N \mathbb{I}[A_i=a] v_i(a)\cdot w_i\cdot y_i
\]
We check consistency and present a small simulation for the case where the selection mechanism depends on the treatment assignment and other pre-treatment variables.
We check that, for this case, the IPW estimand and the estimand produced by Correa, Tian, and Bareinboim (2018) via generalized adjustment criteria are algebraically equivalent.
